Award.AwardTitle: Establishment of a core facility for genome editing at the Marine Biological Laboratory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Model organisms are important to biological research because they enable refined hypothesis testing through precise, repetitive experimental manipulations. Historically, marine labs have played a leading role in providing a broad range of animal models that have been used to answer some of the most fundamental questions in biology, and neuroscience. For example, a fluorescent protein isolated from jellyfish has revolutionized our ability to image the mammalian nervous system and a nerve cell from squid has taught us how electrical signals are created in the brain. Biological research benefits when it embraces diversity. This is because each of the tens of millions of species that exist on earth offers a different insight into a specific biological process. Marine species have existed for much longer than their terrestrial counterparts, and have evolved to occupy far different environments. Accordingly, they offer unique opportunities for science. None of the current major genetic models is a marine organism. This initiative will create a genome editing core facility (GEC) at the Marine Biological Laboratory (MBL http://www.mbl.edu) in Woods Hole which will catalyze the production and development of genetically tractable marine models. This will enable new avenues of genetic research on diverse topics.

Having the facility at the Marine Biological Laboratory will maximize its effectiveness and impact. Every year over 1500 scientists and students visit the Marine Biological Laboratory to conduct research or attend courses, and all of them will have access to the genome editing core facility. The core facility's purpose is to allow the MBL's large community of researchers and students to deliver genome editing reagents to embryos from diverse marine organisms. The facility will consist of three microinjection rigs, apparatus to fabricate injection pipettes, and an electroporator. The rigs will be flexible. They were designed by expert embryologists with years of experience injecting marine embryos and will accommodate specimens that differ in size and material properties. GEC will be housed in the Marine Resource Center, a facility equipped with state-of-the-art equipment to culture a wide variety of marine organisms, including the genetic models that we propose to develop. Because the facility will be open to the entire MBL community, it will be used for both research and education. GEC will support the MBL's strategic aim of creating genetically tractable marine model organisms to catalyze the next generation of novel research in marine biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Model organisms drive biological discovery.  They better enable an investigator to build on past results, reproduce current results and build hypothesis for future testing. By using the same model, scientists at different locations can directly compare findings. Historically, models were selected based on a physical attribute that made them suitable for a particular question. For example, squid were used because their giant nerve fibers made them particularly good to study how nerves work. Without this preparation, our basic understanding of how the brain uses electrical signals to communicate would have been set back years. Model organisms were also diverse.  Cats were used for the neurophysiology of vision. Dogs were used to study respiration and cardiovascular systems. Chickens were used to study development. Fruit flies were to study chromosomes and genetics. Lizards were used to study evolution. Many important models came from the sea. The sea slug opened new frontiers on the study of learning and memory. Sea urchins were used to study early development. The surf clam was used to study cell division, leading to a better mechanistic understanding of the molecular underpinnings of cancer. The electric ray and squid were used to study synaptic transmission. The list goes on.  The established use of diverse marine models put marine labs, and marine biology, in a good position. In more recent decades, however, biological research has moved away these models and focused on small group of organisms because they were among the first to have their genomes sequenced and they are ?genetically tractable.? With them, investigators had the tools to manipulate genes and examine outcomes. This approach became indispensable for modern biology. By consequence, these models have led to most of the major recent advances across disciplines. As things stand, we know a lot about a few organisms. Recently, however, this has started to change. Two recent technological advances are greatly expanding the list of genetically tractable model organisms. First, DNA sequencing is now cheap, and the computational approaches used to assemble it into genomes advanced. Second, novel and generic approaches for gene editing have been development.  The most notable being the CRISPR/Cas9 system for genome editing. In theory, if an organism can be cultured through its lifecycle, it can be made into a genetically tractable model using CRISPR-Cas9. After a severe bottleneck, we are poised on the brink of an explosion of new marine models, allowing us to ask questions that were unapproachable a few years back.

This grant was used to establish a genome editing core facility at the Marine Biological Laboratory. The facility consists of specialized equipment to deliver CRISPR-Cas9 and other gene editing reagents to the embryos of marine organisms. The goal is to create novel gene knockout and transgenic lines that will enable biological discovery across disciplines. Thus far, our facility has been used by 38 researchers representing 20 different labs from 14 different institutions. In total, 18 different aquatic species have been used in the facility. One recent success involved the creation of the first gene knockout in a cephalopod.
